# Idea and Concept

This project was made as part of an assignment during my time at a computer science school. The assignment was given in a course where we learned how to use Visual Studio to create Windows Forms (aka. WinForms) applications. WinForms lets you create applications specifically for Windows and comes with a variety of predefined UI- and layout elements. By now, it is now mostly replaced by Windows Presentation Foundation (aka. WPF), but as WPF has much of the same logic and functionality, learning WinForms was still useful in a way.

This school course only went over the basics of WinForms, and the assignment guidelines/requirements were kept quite loose, so to get some deeper understanding for WinForms and because I already had quite a love for making games at that point, I decided to try to make a little clone of the old Atari game "Atari Breakout".

I thought that Atari Breakout would be a good candidate for this project, as it has very simple gameplay but could still be expanded upon with additional features in case I had some time remaining before the assignment would be due. These additional features could have been something like:

- A scoreboard
- Multiple levels
- Enemies
- Other players (co-op or against each other like pong)

It was also in some ways more challenging to program than pong (which I've already made my own version of) since you also needed to program the targets and add an actual score instead of just counting how many goals each player scored.

# Implementation

A major problem for this project, which I realized nearly immediately during implementation was that Windows Forms was not in any way meant to be used for making games. So much of what would already be around in normal game engines just wasn't there.

This means that much of the logic had to be handwritten. Thankfully, there already was a clock/timer element given which could be used to get updates in set time intervals. With these updates I could run code that is meant to run every frame, basically giving me the same functionality as the "Update" function in Unity. But this was pretty much all the help I got directly through WinForms.

## The Paddle

![](data:image/png;base64,)

This was one of the easier implementations as I just needed the paddle to follow the mouse pointer. Other than that, no logic was needed here.

During each timer tick/update, I checked the mouse position and moved the paddle to the same point on the x-axis. I also needed to account for the size of the application window. If the mouse moved outside of the window, the paddle would try to reach a point outside of its box, so I added a check if the mouse was further left or right of the application window and if so, I would move the paddle all the way to that side while still keeping it inside of its borders.

## The Blocks

![](data:image/png;base64,)

Making the blocks could have been really easy in hindsight, but as I didn't yet know how to create instances of objects with WinForms, and my teacher also didn't or couldn't tell me how, I went ahead and placed every block by hand.

This was a very time-consuming task, made even more time-consuming when I later had to implement the logic for the collision between the ball and the blocks, but more about that in the next text-"block".

## The Ball

![](data:image/png;base64,)

The most code intensive object in this project by far was the ball. It handled basically everything during the game. The collisions with the paddle and the blocks, the check if it had reached the bottom of the screen, and of course it also was the object that moved the most.

The check, if it had reached the bottom of the screen, was thankfully quite easy. I just checked every tick if the ball's position value on the y-axis was below the window's lower boarder and if so, I'd reset the ball, stop its movement until the player presses the start button again and remove one of the lives from the bottom right.

Collision handling with the paddle was also not too difficult to implement. WinForms has a function on most UI-elements that can be called to check if that element is intersecting with another element:

_Element.Bounds.IntersectsWith(OtherElement.Bounds);_

So by checking each tick if the ball intersects with the paddle, I could create something like a collision detection. When that collision happens, I give the ball a new two-dimensional vector with max and min values for its components, and toggle a boolean, making the ball move upwards again.

The real difficulty for me at the time was the collision with the blocks. As I have described in their paragraph, I placed every block manually. All 45 of them. But as I didn't know any easy way to iterate through them at the time, I now had to handle the collisions of all of them individually as well. So please remember when reading the next few lines, that I had to do all of this 45 times.

The collision detection is done the same as between the paddle and the ball. When the ball collides with a block, the block gets hidden, the score is updated, and the balls movement is adjusted.  
If you know a bit about the law of reflection, or have played pool once, you probably know that the angle of incidence always equals the angle of reflection. As I always know the angle/vector at which the ball is moving and I know that all surfaces in the game are always parallel to each other and have only 90Â° corners, I can basically always just mirror the vector that my ball is moving at when a collision happens, and it will move correctly.  
To find out across which axis we have to mirror the vector, we need to figure out if we have collided with an object at its top or bottom or at its sides. This is just always a comparison between the objects' position and sizes and the ball's position and sizes. If the ball has hit the side of a block, the balls vector is mirrored along the y axis. If it hits the top or bottom, the vector is mirrored along the x axis.  
This is done for all blocks, the borders of the application window (except the bottom) and the paddle. The only thing different for the paddle is that the vector is randomized a bit when the ball collides with it, because else the game would be too boring and sometimes not even winnable.

This explains most of the ball movement. Now we just adjust the balls position each tick by the given vector, and we have a correctly moving and colliding ball.

## The Menus

![](data:image/png;base64,)

The game also has some different menus/windows. There's a simple start menu, a pause menu and in theory even a scoreboard menu, but I didn't quite figure out how that worked in time before the submission deadline.

The menus are just different forms that are shown/hidden when the player executes an action that triggers a menu-change, like pressing a button or hitting a specific key.  
As the library I was using is called winForms, handling different forms and switching between them was directly supported by it, which meant that I didn't have to implement a lot of custom code for these.

## The Score

![](data:image/png;base64,)

Making a score for this game was a bit weird, since there's not a lot which could influence the score. If you'd just count how many blocks have been hit, everyone that finishes the game would have the same score, which makes people less eager to replay the game.  
A score should be something that can always be improved, always worked on, and always beaten again by other players.  
To accomplish a more interesting score, I calculated a bonus depending on how much time has passed when hitting a block. This way, players would want to hit the blocks as fast as possible, because the longer they take, the less points they will get for each block. This should encourage quicker actions from the player or even have some players create strategies to hit as many blocks as soon as possible.

In hindsight, there would have been more interesting ways to influence the score. Maybe by giving a bonus to every additional block that has been hit before the ball has been touched by the paddle again, creating something like a combo meter. Or maybe something as simple as adding a penalty for each live lost.

# Conclusion

I am quite happy with what I learned throughout the process of making this game. Yes, the code isn't anything special, and it is just a clone of a very simple game, but I did some decent problem solving and managed to work with the tools I had, even if they weren't meant to be used for making a game.

After this project, I decided to move to some actual game engines next, to get some better tools for my projects and also learn how to use them correctly.  
Even though this project worked out in the end with WinForms, it would turn out to be not quite usable for most other types of games I wanted to do. A big reason why I wanted to switch away from it, next to the non-existing support for physics, collisions and all that, was the very limited visual options. You couldn't even do transparent backgrounds, so anything using characters, environments or other assets would have had to be done as boxes. Even the ball in this game isn't actually round. It just has a black background, so you don't see its border box all the time.  
I decided that this would be too limiting for me, so I moved on to new adventures on new engines, which would be meant for making games this time.
